facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1194, 1196, 1197, 1250 of 1967 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1194, 11 96, 1197 1250 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from Bombay High Court judgment dated November 22, 23 and 24, 1966 in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1476 and 1424 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated November 22, 23 and 24, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1476 and 1424 of 1966.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petitions in Bombay High Court challenging validity of Borough Municipalities Validation of Certain Taxes on Buildings and Lands Act, 1965 (Maharashtra Act No. 111 of 1966).

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in these appeals filed writ peti- tions in the Bombay High Court challenging the validity of the Borough Municipalities  Validation of Certain Taxes on Buildings and Lands  Act, 1965  Maharashtra Act No. 111 of 1966 , hereinafter called the Validating Act,

facts.text: Writ petitions challenged Validating Act on ground of violating Article 14 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the provisions of the Act violated their fundamental rights under Art. 14 of the Constitution

facts.text: Writ petitions sought restraining appellants from levying or collecting house tax on mills, factories and buildings connected therewith of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: and for restraining the appellants from levying house tax on the mills, factories and buildings companynected therewith of the respondents or companylecting the same from them.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Division Bench held sections 3(b), 4(1), 4(2) and 5 of Validating Act invalid as contravening Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court held that sections 3 b , 4 1 , 4 2  and 5 of the Validating Act were invalid as they companytravened Art. 14

facts.text: High Court granted prayer restraining appellant-Municipality from levying and collecting the tax.

anchor.surface_text: and granted the prayer for restraining the appellant-Municipality from levying and companylecting the tax.

facts.text: Till 1947, appellant-Municipality levied house tax on mills, factories and buildings connected therewith on basis of annual letting value ascertained normally.

anchor.surface_text: Till the year 1947, the appellant-Municipality used to levy house tax on the mills, factories and buildings companynected therewith of the respondents in these appeals on the basis of their annual letting value and the annual letting value for this purpose was ascertained in the numbermal way,

facts.text: In 1947, appellant-Municipality made fresh rules for levy of house tax including rule 2(c).

anchor.surface_text: In 1947, the appellant-Municipality made fresh rules for levy of house tax and rule 2  c  of the new rules ran as follows

facts.text: Rule 2(c) levied house tax on mills, factories and buildings connected therewith at Rs. 40/- for every 100 square feet of floor area.

anchor.surface_text: 2 c  In the case of mills and factories and buildings companynected therewith, house tax on buildings shall be levied at the usual rate on the annual rental value fixed at Rs. 40/- for every 100 square feet or portions thereof for each sterey, floor or cellar.

facts.text: Lokamanya Mills Barsi Limited filed 4 suits claiming refund of amounts paid under rule 2(c) as ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: One of the respondents, namely, Lokamanya Mills. Barsi, Limited, claimed refund of amounts paid by them on the basis that Rule 2 c  was ultra vires the Boroughs Act and they filed 4 suits for the same.

facts.text: Suits dismissed, appeals preferred to Supreme Court, disposed in Lokamanya Mills Barsi Ltd. v. Barsi Borough Municipality (1962 1 SCR 306).

anchor.surface_text: Against the decrees dismissing the suits, appeals were preferred to this Court and they were finally disposed of by this Court in Lokamanya Mills, Barsi Ltd. v. Barsi Borough Municipality 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court held rule 2(c) ultra vires Boroughs Act as it used floor area instead of annual letting value or capital value.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, after referring to the provisions of S. 78 and the explanation to S. 75 of the Boroughs Act, held that the Municipality companyld levy a rate on lands and buildings on the basis of their capital or annual letting value and that in framing rule 2 c , the Municipality had adopted a mode of valuation different from the one sanctioned by the Boroughs Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals and decreed the suits in Lokamanya Mills case.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Court allowed the appeals and decreed the suits.

facts.text: Validating Act aimed to enable levy of house tax on mills etc on basis of rule 2(c) and validate past levy and collection retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: The main objects of the Validatting Act were to enable the municipalities governed by the Boroughs Act to levy house tax on mills factories and buildings companynected therewith on the basis of rule 2 c  and to validate the levy and companylection of the tax with retrospective effect.

facts.text: Validating Act amends Boroughs Act by inserting clause in s.3 and substituting explanation to s.75 to allow floor area basis for mills etc.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of ,the, Validating Act  1  1962 1 S.C.R. 306. brings about certain amendments in the Boroughs Act. In s. 3 of the Boroughs Act, a clause is inserted which lays down that rate on buildings or lands includes any tax imposed on buildings or lands. Another amendment introduced in the Boroughs Act is with reference to Explanation to s. 75. ... Explanation For the purposes of a rate on buildings or lands, the basis of valuation may be the annual letting value. the annual value the floor area, in the case of mills, factories buildings and lands companynected therewith the capital value in the case of vacant lands.

facts.text: Amendments in Validating Act given retrospective effect from commencement of Boroughs Act.

anchor.surface_text: Both these amendments were given retrospective effect from the companymencement of the Boroughs Act.

facts.text: Sections 4 and 5 of Validating Act validate levy and collection of tax retrospectively notwithstanding Supreme Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 4 and 5 of the Validating Act are designed to validate with retrospective effect, the levy and companylection of tax numberwithstanding the decision of this Court.

facts.text: Rule 2(c) struck down by Supreme Court in Lokamanya Mills case.

anchor.surface_text: It may be recalled that rule, 2  c  was struck down by this Court in Lokamanya Mills, Barsi Ltd. v. Barsi Borough Muni- cipality

facts.text: After rule 2(c) struck down, no new rule framed under s.75 of Boroughs Act for house tax on mills etc.

anchor.surface_text: After rule 2 c  was struck down, the Municipality did number frame any rule under the provision of S. 75 of the Boroughs Act for imposing house tax on mills factories or buildings companynected therewith.

facts.text: Validating Act does not revive or resurrect rule 2(c).

anchor.surface_text: The Validating Act has number also revived or resurrected rule 2 c .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds there is no charging provision for house tax on mills etc without rule 2(c).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the position was ,that there was numbercharging provision for imposition of house tax on the mills, factories or buildings companynected therewith.

facts.text: High Court right in restraining Municipality from levying house tax on mills etc and quashing demand notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in restraining the appellant-Municipality from levying house tax on the mills, factories or buildings companynected therewith of the respondents and in quashing the demand numberice issued.

facts.text: Section 4 of Validating Act does not resurrect rule 2(c) with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 did number resurrect rule 2 c  with retrospective effect in order that it might be said that there was, in the eye of law, a provision for charging house tax on mills, factories or buildings companynected therewith so that the tax levied and companylected might be validated.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals with no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeals but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.

holdings.text: When rule 2(c) was struck down, the effect was that the rule could never be deemed to have been passed

anchor.surface_text: When the rule was struck down by this Court, the effect was, that the rule could never be deemed to have been passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Lokamanya Mills holding rule ultra vires; applies doctrine that invalid subordinate legislation is void ab initio

holdings.text: Apart from rule 2(c), there was no charging provision either in the Boroughs Act or in the Validating Act for levying house tax on mills, factories and buildings connected therewith

anchor.surface_text: Apart from rule 2 c , there was no charging provision similar to rule 2 c  either in the Boroughs Act, or in the Validating Act for levying house tax on mills, factories and buildings connected therewith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of Boroughs Act and Validating Act confirms absence of alternative charging mechanism post-striking down of rule 2(c)

holdings.text: The Validating Act has not revived or resurrected rule 2(c)

anchor.surface_text: The Validating Act has not also revived or resurrected rule 2 c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No explicit language in Validating Act reviving the struck-down rule

holdings.text: There was no charging provision for imposition of house tax on the mills, factories or buildings connected therewith

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the position was that there was no charging provision for imposition of house tax on the mills, factories or buildings connected therewith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of striking down rule 2(c), no alternative provision, and no revival leads to absence of charging authority

holdings.text: The explanation to s.75 only provides for floor area as basis of valuation but does not constitute a charging provision

anchor.surface_text: All that the explanation to s. 75 substituted by the Validating Act did was to enact that, for imposing house tax, floor area will be the basis of valuation in the case of mills, factories or buildings connected therewith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes between valuation basis and charging provision required for tax levy

holdings.text: The High Court was right in restraining the appellant-Municipality from levying house tax and in quashing the demand notice

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in restraining the appellant-Municipality from levying house tax on the mills, factories or buildings connected therewith of the respondents and in quashing the demand notice issued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above conclusions to facts; no valid basis for levy

holdings.text: Section 4 did not resurrect rule 2(c) with retrospective effect

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 did not resurrect rule 2 c  with retrospective effect in order that it might be said that there was, in the eye of law, a provision for charging house tax on mills, factories or buildings connected therewith so that the tax levied and collected might be validated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.4 shows no language resurrecting or retrospectively validating the specific rule

holdings.text: There is no occasion to reach the constitutional question as regards the validity of the impugned sections of the Validating Act

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we have no occasion to reach the constitutional question as regards the validity of the impugned sections of the Validating Act and we express no opinion upon it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case disposed on statutory grounds; applies doctrine of avoidance of constitutional questions

holdings.text: It was not necessary for the High Court to have struck down the provisions of sections 3(b), 4(1), 4(2) and 5 of the Validating Act

anchor.surface_text: We think that it was not necessary for the High Court to have struck down the provisions of sections 3 b , 4 1 , 4 2  and 5 of the Validating Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reliefs could be granted without declaring provisions unconstitutional given statutory invalidity of levy

holdings.text: Even if s.4 had resurrected rule 2(c) with retrospective effect, that might not have cured invalidity on account of violation of Art.14 as it imposed a flat rate without classification

anchor.surface_text: Even if s. 4 had resurrected rule 2 c  and said that it shall be deemed to have been passed under the Validating Act with retrospective effect, that might not have cured invalidity on account of its being violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution as it imposed a flat rate on the floor area without making any classification of the area on the basis of income, productivity or age of building, etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical application of Art.14 reasonable classification test to flat rate floor area valuation

holdings.text: It is a wise tradition with Courts not to decide a constitutional question if the case can be disposed of on other grounds

anchor.surface_text: It is a wise tradition with Courts not to decide a constitutional question if the case can be disposed of on other grounds.

precedents.cited_proposition: Rule 2(c) is ultra vires the Boroughs Act as it levies house tax on floor area basis instead of annual letting value or capital value, assuming uniformity of return per square foot and depriving rate-payer of right to object to valuation
precedents.cited_holding: The vice of the rule lies in an assumed uniformity of return per square foot which structures of different classes which are in their nature number similar, may reasonably fetch if let out to tenants and in the virtual deprivation to the rate-payer of his statutory right to object to the valuation.
